I use citric acid to clean some parts of an EDM machine. In particular there is a small wheel (it might be ceramic or porcelain) that comes in contact with a thin, fragile, metal wire which is being run through the machine constantly. We use this chemical called saven which dampens the conductivity of the water in order to better control the discharge. Over time the saven will build up on the wheel which if left alone will cause it to stop turning and the wire to break. We can't just scrub it off because that might rough the surface of the wheel and again cause the wire to break. So we place it in a beaker of citric acid and place that beaker in an ultrasonic cleaner (with a fixture of course).

We actually use citric acid in biochemistry: When you make a buffer, you need to look at the pH range of the buffer to choose which acid or base to use. Citric acid is great for a pH between 2.6 and 7.6. These pH are perfect for yeast and a lot of bacteria.

Citric acid is not exciting for synthetic chemistry.  With that said I find pure citric acid profoundly useful. Me and my wife go through several ounces a month for cleaning,  especially bathrooms or where limestone deposits are a problem.  Next, hot  dilute citric acid is very good for cleaning rusty steel as it does not attack the metal like hydrochloric acid.  Citric acid reacts with rust stains in clothing and if placed in direct sunlight,  the ferric iron is reduced to colorless/weakly colored ferrous citrate and can be laundered out.  Citric acid is indispensable in using acid dyestuffs on wool, silk and other protein fibers.  Citric acid may be useful in electroplating due to metal chelation but I haven’t searched the journals yet.

Ok, I've had some experience with citric acid...and...discovered why its so widely used in so many foods and drinks.
My discovery involved making a mango drink. Its also the same with any fruit drink...or, candy...or...
Ok, now the fruit and water was just bland.
Strawberrys or any fruit for that matter will just lose much of its natural flavor upon the destructive blending process...not sure about the physics or chemistry involved in this flavor loss, but trust me, it goes away.
Adding sugar slightly improves the taste, but restoration of the natural zing is not what happens. It was just missing something and even increasing the volume of fruit used didn't work. Enter the magic...
Adding citric acid soured the taste, but multiplied the flavor very much. Adding sugar to offset the sour of the acid produced not only the missing flavor of the fruit, but actually multiplied it many times.
Ah! Its making sense why its in so many things now. So I used less and less fruit until I took a small fraction of fruit I previously used in an experiment.
Only two Strawberrys, a gallon of water, two teaspoons of citric acid and a cup of sugar produces a very Strawberry-eee drink...
So in conclusion, its also a natural preservative, and produces the strong flavors we get in the candies and things we buy. Its safe to say this is something food makers would rather be unknown generally.

Citric acid + Sodium Chlorite (NaClO2) = chlorine dioxide gas (ClO2) a wonderful and safe surface cleaner and potable water purifier for camping.  Three drops of 50% citric acid and three drops of 25% sodium chlorite in 120 ml (4 oz) of water will produce about 25 parts per million (ppm) chlorine dioxide (ClO2) gas, invisibly suspended in the water.  NASA has called this the "universal antidote." Do NOT confuse sodium chlorite (NaClO2) with sodium HYPOchlorite (NaClO) which is pure bleach and should never be ingested.

By the way in this case I have some doubts. Everything is well-explained of course, but I do not agree when you use sulfuric acid, since, diffrently from what you said in the video, I'm pretty sure that CaSO4 is indeed solubile in water (2g/L even at room temperature). Using H3PO4 might be the best choice, since it forms insolubile Ca3(PO4)2. Moreover, form your calculation it seems that you use less acid than the stoichiometric amount, not considering the pKa values of the carboxyl groups, nor the acid second proton pKa (you should have monitored the pH in this phase). So, due to these facts, I imagine you recovered, mostly calcium sulfate (I think gypsum looking the crystals), and partially deprotoned citrate (among with some impurities of course). In order to be sure, you might check the melting point of what you recovered.

Here's one more use for Citric Acid: cheese making.
1/2 gallon milk
1 tsp salt
1 tsp citric acid dissolved in 2-3 oz of warm water (alternately 1/3 cup lemon juice or vinegar)
Heat the milk and salt on low to 185-190 F (Do NOT go above 200, or let the milk boil).
Once temp is reached immediately take the citric acid solution, and mix it in the heated milk.
Stir constantly for 2-3 minutes, or until a fairly large amount of curds have formed. If after 5 minutes there aren't very many curds, add another 1/2 tsp of citric acid dissolved in 2-3 oz of warm water, and continue stirring. If no curds form after this, then you let the milk get above 200 degrees, and will have to waste the milk.
Let the milk sit undisturbed for 15 minutes.
Use cheese cloth and a colander to gravity-filter the curds from the whey.
After most of the whey has filtered out, pull the cheesecloth up around the cheese, and hang it for an hour or two, to drain the rest of the whey off.

And now you have fresh homemade ricotta cheese. How's that for edible chemistry?

Foodgrade 100% pure citric acid on Amazon runs about $15 for 5 pounds.  Or if you want about twice that it is about $2 a pound.  That puts it at a lower price than standard sugar (sucrose), so if you want to get this stuff, it's practically free online for all sorts of purposes including wine-making.  It's a great acid to balance out mushroom substrates.  I use it in my Panellous Stipticus bags (a famous green-glowing oyster-like mushroom that is mildly toxic but just awesome looking)  to bring the enriched sawdust substrate to around 4 pH (which lowers more as the mycelium grows to close to 3.5 - the ideal pH for the species in terms of glow).  No other acid works as well for that purpose that I know about.  It's fairly gentle, completely non-toxic, and survives sterilization just fine.  It's great for making sour candies too!  I think everyone should have some around!

The difference in solubility of sodium citrate and calcium citrate is exploited when taking blood samples: when we take a sample in a Carolina Blue top tube, it contains sodium citrate. This reacts with calcium ions in the blood, forming a not very soluble salt that precipitates out. This sequesters the calcium from the blood, which is an essential component of the clotting cascade, and we end up with a sample of whole blood that doesn't clot. We can then centrifuge the blood and measure the activity of the coagulation factors in plasma to find out how well they are working in order to find clotting defects. It is not necessary to heat things up like NileRed is doing here, just mixing things thoroughly is enough to sequester enough calcium for the clotting to be insignificant.

Nile, love your videos.  I used to study citric acid crystals.  It appears to me that you actually grew a batch of citric acid monohydrate crystals.  The hexagonal plate you saw in crystal 5 is indicative of anhydrous citric acid, as these crystals form hexagonal plates.  Crystal 3 to me just appeared to be a twinned citric acid monohydrate crystal.  Citric acid monohydrate crystals can actually grow fairly large when they are pure and left to sit if you were looking for something to do with them.  I used to get them larger than a cm in diameter in a day or two.  If you keep the crystals out for a day or two in a higher temperature environment, you would probably be able to see the crystals dehydrate and turn amorphous.  Keep up the videos!

You could use the citric acid to make a biodegradable polyester. To do this, you let it react with glycerol at 130°C for about 10-15 minutes. When talking about the pKa of the carboxylic groups of citric acid, you denoted the one on the right to have a pKa of 6.40, but the one on the left to have 4.76. It might be worth noting that these two groups are exactly the same. I assume you mean that the first carboxylic group to lose its proton is the middle one. After this, one of the side groups will get deprotonated, and the pKa of this is 4.76. Once two depronotations have happened, the pKa of the last proton is 6.40.
